title-group.article-title: Application of Bioengineering Modalities in Vascular Research: Evaluating the Clinical Gain

article-meta.aff: 1Department of Vascular Surgery, “Democritus” University of Thrace, University Hospital of Alexandroupolis, Alexandroupolis, Greece
2Fluids Section, School of Mechanical Engineering, National Technical University of Athens, Athens, Greece
4Department of Vascular Surgery, University of Crete, University Hospital of Heraklion, Heraklion, Greece

author-notes.corresp: Efstratios Georgakarakos, Department of Vascular Surgery, University Hospital of Alexandroupolis, Greece Email: efstratiosgeorg@gmail.com

abstract.p: Using knowledge gained from bioengineering studies, current vascular research focuses on the delineation of the natural history and risk assessment of clinical vascular entities with significant morbidity and mortality, making the development of new, more accurate predictive criteria a great challenge. Additionally, conclusions derived from computational simulation studies have enabled the improvement and modification of many biotechnology products that are used routinely in the treatment of vascular diseases. This review highlights the promising role of the bioengineering applications in the vascular field.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Computational modeling of arterial biomechanics has provided a powerful research tool to study the pathogenesis and natural history of vascular diseases. Current advances in this field seem promising in developing new predictive criteria and planning an individualized, patient-specific therapeutic strategy for a group of clinical entities with significant morbidity and mortality, such as abdominal aortic aneurysms (AAAs), extracranial carotid artery disease (carotid stenosis), and atheromatosis of the peripheral arteries.

Furthermore, the utilization of the bioengineering applications in the assessment and evaluation of current treatment modalities can lead to the improvement or development of new therapeutic devices. This review discusses the aforementioned aspects from the clinical point of view, the major points of which are depicted in Table 1.

caption.p: The Contribution of Bioengineering to Problem–Solution in Certain Vascular Fields

tr.td: Design and number of struts affect stress values
Drag forces influenced by redistribution of stresses on sac and local geometry
High stress associated with high growth rate

fn.p: Abbreviations: PAD, peripheral arterial disease; AAA, abdominal aortic aneurysms.

sec.title: Evolving the Computational Techniques
sec.p: Finite element analysis (FEA) technique has a fundamental role in the computational research of biological systems, utilizing small subsections (elements) of 3-dimentional (3D) structures (Figure 1) created by segmentation and meshing. 1 Computational flow dynamic (CFD) approaches use numerical methods and algorithms to analyze problems that involve fluid flows, by solving Navier-Stokes equations for all finite elements of the model. Fluid structure interaction (FSI) methods compound fluid and structural equations, solved either simultaneously (monolithic approach) or separately (partitioned approach), in order to determine the flow fields and solid body stresses on a deformable model. Most researchers acquire information on the 3D AAA realistic, complex geometric configuration using patient-specific DICOM data derived from high-resolution spiral computed tomography (CT) or magnetic resonance angiography. 2,3

caption.p: The aneurysm surface mesh (left) created for the computed model. The reconstruction of the total wall thickness is modified by the local thrombus thickness (sagittal section, right).

sec.p:
More advanced techniques were also refined and used to study the impact of blood flow to the distribution and range of the stress values, taking into account the interaction between the pulsatile blood flow and the deformities of the wall material configuration as well as the non-Newtonian properties of blood. 4
–8 Finally, the use of the backward incremental method for the determination of the initial stress in the zero-pressure state and the effect of the latter in the distribution of stresses maximum values is expected to increase the accuracy of future computational estimations. 9
–12

sec.title: Advances in Risk Stratification for Future Cerebrovascular Events
sec.p: In clinical practice, there is an agreement regarding the treatment of high-grade carotid stenoses. Carotid endarterectomy (CEA) is recommended in symptomatic patients with >50% stenosis (if the perioperative stroke/death rate is <6%), whereas CEA is also recommended in asymptomatic men younger than 75 years with 70% to 99% stenosis, if the perioperative stroke/death risk 13 is <3%. There is evidence that the risk of hemispheric events in carotid disease is also influenced strongly by other factors apart from the degree of stenosis, such as the plaque components and morphology, reflected in its echolucency, the fibrous cap thinning, and the hemorrhagic areas within the plaque, all affecting the plaque vulnerability. 14,15 Furthermore, Tang et al demonstrated no significant relationship between the degree of lumen stenosis and inflammation, a well-recognized predictor of vulnerable plaque, whereas inflammation correlates sufficiently with tensile stress within atheromatic plaques. 16,17

Since much of the gained knowledge and therapeutic guidelines applied on individuals with a specific carotid stenosis are based on the estimated probability of stroke derived from a large patient population with the same stenosis degree, there is no certain way to estimate the individual recurrence risk of an episode of transient ischemic attack (TIA) or assess the probability of progression to an attack of greater severity (stroke) on a patient-specific basis. Therefore, much can be gained from an individualized patient-specific analysis of cerebrovascular event risk, based on specific biomechanical factors that may render some carotid plaques vulnerable to the aforementioned events. 18 The combination of high-resolution magnetic resonance imaging and FEA or FSI techniques gave rise to interesting conclusions regarding the promising role of biomechanical stresses in cerebrovascular risk stratification. Gao et al reported a good correlation between high local stress concentrations and plaque rupture sites. 19 The magnitude and distribution of tensile stress depend on the thickness of the fibrous cap, the lipid core size, and the geometric configuration of the plaque, with the highest values located in the shoulder of the plaque at the point of plaque transition to normal endothelium. 20 –22 Ruptured plaques were associated with higher stress values than asymptomatic ones. 23 A prospective study by Sadat et al showed that high biomechanical (tensile) stresses were independent factors strongly correlated to cerebrovascular events, in addition to rupture of a thin fibrous cap and plaque hemorrhage. 24

Soloperto et al reported that while low and/or oscillatory shear stress promotes plaque destabilization and consequent vulnerability, the tensile stress contributes the most to the plaque rupture and the progression of symptomatic events. 25 More interestingly, Sadat et al studied the stress profiles between symptomatic and nonsymptomatic patients with moderate stenoses and identified a correlation between high levels of maximum critical stresses and neurological events (TIA or stroke) in contrast to the asymptomatic group, whereas a difference in maximum critical stress values was also observed between single and multiple episodes of TIAs. 26 The complementary role of maximum tensile stress to the degree of stenosis regarding the prediction of plaque rupture risk is depicted in a study by Li et al, according to which some plaques with moderate stenosis but high stress values associated with thin fibrous cap demonstrate a rupture risk comparable with plaques with high degree of stenosis (>70%). 27

sec.title: The AAAs: Toward a New Rupture Risk Stratification and Growth Rate Prediction
Association of Wall Stress With Rupture Susceptibility
sec.p:
The biomechanical approach can offer a new insight into the estimation of AAA rupture risk predicion. 1 Wall stress analysis (von Mises stress, Figure 2) can be performed with high interoperator and intraoperator reliability. 28,29 Ruptured AAAs show higher peak wall stress (PWS) values than electively repaired AAAs, even when matched for diameter and blood pressure. 29
–34 Fillinger et al was the first to show that PWS values could differentiate AAAs that required urgent repair better than the maximum diameter criterion. In this study, low-stress aneurysms presented a lower rupture rate, while high-stress aneurysms presented a higher rupture rate, regardless of size. 34 According to the study, the elevated values were not simply a sudden, incidental event near the time of mechanical failure expressed as rupture, but rather a characteristic that could be early recognized, serving possibly as a predictive index prior to rupture.

caption.p: The stress distribution for the AAA model. The color scale enables the determination of the areas with highest and lowest stress values.

sec.p:
The pathophysiologic association of PWS with risk rupture can be useful as a validation tool for other factors, easier to estimate and use, such as the geometric parameters of the aneurysm. The effect that the AAA geometric variations regarding the neck or the iliac bifurcation angle can impose on the flow fields within the sac and the range, height, and distribution of stress values has been clearly demonstrated by Li and Kleinstreuer. 35 Numerous studies have reported a strong association between PWS values and certain characteristics of the AAA, such as the tortuosity and the curvature of the lumen centerline. 36
–39 Furthermore, Xenos et al showed that the PWS values increase as the iliac angle increases. Specifically, the increase in the iliac bifurcation angle is associated with constantly high stress values of von Mises stress values in this area. 40

sec.title: In Search for a Predictive Factor of Small AAAs Growth Rate
sec.p: The growing interest for the importance and utility of the geometric factors emerges from various reports suggesting a predictive role for geometry regarding the rupture risk of an AAA. Interestingly, a recent systemic review including patients with large (>6.0 cm) AAAs who had been randomized in endovascular aneurysm repair (EVAR) 2 trial (for being ineligible to sustain open repair) implied that those with shorter AAA neck lengths (<2.5 cm) appeared to have higher rupture rates compared with those with longer neck lengths (>2.5 cm), although this finding was of borderline significance (P = .10) and, therefore, deserves meticulous interpretation. 41,42 Furthermore, the anatomic suitability for endovascular treatment (ie, AAA neck of appropriate fixation zone, not too angulated and accompanied with appropriate iliac landing zones) appeared to correlate with lower incidence of rupture, since these patients randomized in EVAR 2 had a rupture rate of 17 per 100 patient-years, significantly lower than the overall rate reported in the aforementioned meta-analysis (27 per 100 patient-years in those unsuitable for EVAR). 42 Additional data are needed to delineate the natural history of large AAAs and the bioengineering tools are of outmost importance toward this direction.

The issue of predicting the growth rate of small AAA (≤5.5 cm) is much more challenging since there is a growing tendency in the literature in favor of early EVAR in this category, claiming that a significant percentage will be losing the EVAR eligibility by the time it reaches the diameter threshold criteria, 43 despite the discouraging results of 2 recent randomized controlled trials that advocated in favor of the safety of “watchful waiting” for the small AAAs. 44,45 Thompson et al noticed that small AAA growth rate may present a bimodal pattern, with nearly half of all AAAs never progressing to rupture or to fulfill the criteria for elective repair. 46 Although no one supports the early treatment of AAAs <4.0 cm, there is still an uncertainty for the 4.0 to 5.0 cm range, where a specific subgroup of rapid growth remains hidden. 47 It is this crucial field, where the bioengineering research may help the clinicians out by attributing to the identification of the rapid growth of small AAAs or those, even few, prone to rupture, thus adding evidence for the justification of cost of early endovascular intervention. Early reports to this direction deserve further attention. Indeed, high values of wall stress at the inflection site between the neck and the AAA sac have been recently reported to strongly correlate with rapid growth rate of small AAAs. 48 In another study, medium or high wall stress was associated with a higher growth rate compared to a relative low wall stress. 49 Furthermore, wall stress has been found to be 12% more specific and 13% more sensitive in rupture prediction than maximum diameter alone, 50 whereas local anatomy can affect the AAA growth rate by 1.5-fold greater than traditional risk factors such as smoking, age, hypertension, gender, heart disease, hypercholesterolemia, renal failure, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, diabetes mellitus, and peripheral disease.

The abovementioned findings seem to justify the optimistic perspective of identifying useful factors in order to predict the hemodynamic behavior of small AAAs. However, despite the fact that information derived from noninvasive image-based methods have a potential to serve reliable and valuable adjunctive clinical tools, one could be skeptical whether any one of the proposed geometrical indices or stress values alone could become the sole reliable index of rupture risk or a threshold for elective repair. 51
–54 Therefore, the complete geometry and a positive correlation of a set of geometric indices, among which the reliable estimation of AAA wall thickness still remain a considerable problem to be solved, and/or a combination with wall stress should be considered to assess the potential for rupture or rapid growth. 54
–58

sec.title: Clinical Applications of Bioengineering in Clinical Practice
Modifying the Design and Performance of Stents in Peripheral Vascular Disease
sec.p: Vascular remodeling after balloon angioplasty is mediated by wall circumferential and shear stress (WSS), both implicated in the process of myointimal hyperplasia. 59,60 Therefore, since the use of stents in peripheral arterial disease has become a common practice, in order to improve the angioplasty results, the research interest is focused on the mechanical behavior of stents, their interaction with the treated arterial segment as well as their association with the induction of intimal hyperplasia, in order to modify the technical characteristics of stents and delay the stenosis recurrence, thus improving our treatment modalities. It is showed that neointimal growth is associated with local blood flow patterns, the latter being directly affected by the stent design and spacing. 61,62 Stents with reduced intersection between their struts promote less neointimal hyperplasia. Flow stagnation and separation areas within the arterial stented segment rely mostly on the stent strut spacing, regardless of the complexicity of the vessel geometries, while the arterial wall near the strut regions sustains the highest circumferential stress values. 62 Also, shear stress appears to be higher in closely packed struts. 63 The CFD techniques also help to estimate the circumferential (hoop) stress more precisely than the classic Law of Laplace, thus delineating the differences of various stent designs, when applied to atherosclerotic plaques of different stiffness. 64

It has been demonstrated that there is a considerable difference in the arterial wall circumferential stress between stents of variable compliance when a stiff atherosclerotic plaque is involved, with the stiffer stents causing significantly higher stress values than the more compliant ones, while this difference in stress was almost offset when applied over a less stiff plaque. 64 Interestingly, the lumen dilatation was dependent only on stent design (with stiffer stents performing marginally better than more compliant ones) and not on the plaque material properties. 65 The direct clinical implication derived from this observation is that more rigid stents would be preferable for softer, lipid-laden plaques, while a rigid, more calcified plaque can be adequately treated with a less stiff stent, avoiding to promote high stresses that would predispose to hyperplasia. This also holds true for the tapered arteries, where the application of stiffer stents promote much higher stresses compared to more compliant designs. 65 Toward the path of improving the performance of the stenting materials, FEA methods can also contribute to the estimation and comparison of the fatigue resistance between different materials. 66

Another important determinant factor predisposing to neointimal hyperplasia, WSS, has been found to be influenced by the configuration and number of stent struts. LaDisa et al suggested that the polygonal cross-sectional post-stent vascular geometry may be associated with increases in the area subjected to low WSS or high gradients of WSS, whereas the increase in the number of stent–struts intersections leads to a more circular vessel geometry, thus reducing the abovementioned alterations. 67

Noteworthy, the impact of nonidealized, patient-specific geometries in association with vessel deformations caused by either stent implantation or limb movements may draw additional conclusions about the interaction between vessels and stenting materials, affecting potentially our everyday practice. For example, the difference between the desired and the actual length of the stent after its deployment (foreshortening) within the artery has been shown to increase the density of the strut areas, which in association with the caused misalignment in the struts leads to elevated WSS gradients and higher risk of intimal hyperplasia. 68 The latter may also hold true in cases of asymmetric stent deployment or vessel straightening due to inflexible stents, altering the vessel curvature and the local flow patterns. 69 Additionally, taking into account the dynamic changes of the lower limb vessels during flexion and extension can unmask additional hemodynamic impairments that predispose to stent failure or restenosis, thus, modifying the stent design accordingly. 70 –72

sec.title: Studying the Hemodynamic Behavior of AAAs After Stent-Graft Implantation
sec.p: Although the evolvement of stent grafts over the last 2 decades made the endovascular treatment of electively repaired AAAs common practice, many crucial issues still remain to be resolved yet, the most important of which are the determination of the parameters leading to the device migration as well as to the development of endoleaks. Admittedly, only few studies have performed flow analysis related to endoleaks. Although an association between type II endoleaks with inlet branch pressure has been demonstated, 73 –75 there seems to be a discrepancy between the generated intrasac pressure and the fate of the AAA sac, in terms of endotension and sac shrinkage. 76 Therefore, factors other than hemodynamic parameters may also determine the successful regression of a stented AAA. However, the study of hemodynamic parameters appears more promising in the estimation of stent-graft migration.

Currently, numerical modeling of endovascular-treated AAA is used to determine the stresses and forces developed on AAA sac and stent-graft materials in vivo, estimating hemodynamic parameters, such as the pressure distribution over the main body, the bifurcation, the limbs of a stent graft (Figure 3), or the drag forces predisposing to graft migration. Using FSI analysis, Molony et al reported that the stress exerted on the AAA wall was reduced after the insertion of the stent graft and its maximum values were redistributed at the AAA neck and iliac leg areas. 77 The peak postoperative axial drag force increased in the follow-up model, attributed to postoperative remodeling of the AAA wall, due to sac shrinkage. Furthermore, it was found that the drag force is influenced by the AAA neck angle, the iliac bifurcation angle, the main body/iliac–leg diameter ratio, the size of the stent graft, the cardiac cycle, and the blood pressure waveform. 78 An increase in proximal neck or iliac angulation correlates with an increase in drag force, the primary vector of which lies either in the anterocaudal or in the sideway direction. 79,80

caption.p: The pressure contour over the main body, the bifurcation area and the limbs of the stent graft.

sec.p: Important as it may seem, the aforementioned studies take into account the geometric configuration of a given, instant “snap shot” of the CT, applying thereafter the FSI technique. However, the distention of the stent-graft landing zones is significant preoperatively and remains preserved after the stent-graft placement, both in the anteroposterior and lateral direction. 81 The aorta exhibits clearly a wide variety of morphologic changes throughout the cardiac cycle. Dynamic CT is a reliable modality to investigate these AAA and stent-graft changes during the cardiac cycle. 82 Indeed, Teutelink et al reported large variances before and after the stent-graft implantation, regarding the aortic neck pulsatility, area, and diameter, with maximum changes of up to 15%, implicating even the need for individualized stent-graft oversizing based on dynamic CT studies instead of static CT. 83,84 Pol et al also found a significant difference in the pulsatility of the distal landing zones of the stent graft (common iliac arteries). 85

van Kaulen et al recently studied 2 groups of patients after endovascular treatment with neither significant differences in aortic neck characteristics (angulation, neck and diameter) nor graft oversizing and concluded that the significant difference in the preoperative heartbeat-dependent aortic diameter increase and aortic area increase between the 2 groups of patients was a significant predictor for the stent migration that occurred in the group with the higher values. 86

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Bioengineering tools provide promising methods to delineate the natural history of lethal pathological conditions, thus changing, modifying, and evolving our treatment strategies in an individualized, patient-specific basis. 87 Furthermore, computational simulation helps to validate the current treatment modalities, providing evidence, ideas, and suggestions for the development and improvement of the current therapeutic devices, such as the ideal configuration and the mechanical properties of stent grafts as well as the mechanical behavior of the materials incorporated in stent grafts. Future studies are expected to provide a new insight into vascular diseases.

fn.p: The author(s) declared no potential conflicts of interest with respect to the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
The author(s) received no financial support for the research, authorship, and/or publication of this article.
